text:
In this video, you'll learn about AWS 
Glue data integration differentiators.

With the AWS Glue data integration 
service, you get serverless scalability

and pricing for extract, transform, 
and load (ETL) jobs, multiple authoring

experiences that foster collaboration 
and productivity, and the ability to create
custom visual transformations for your business.

Developers and data engineers run ETL jobs on 
periodic schedules or based on event triggers.

However, most data integration offerings
have a significant amount of idle time.

Furthermore, volume can fluctuate 
throughout the day, requiring various

levels of compute power 
for even the same ETL job.

With AWS Glue, when an ETL Job is 
launched, servers are spun up in seconds

to perform the necessary tasks and then shut 
down immediately when the job is completed.
This ensures that ETL developers and

data engineers only pay for the 
resources they use during the job.

This serverless approach is a 
game-changer for data integration,

empowering customers to focus on their
 data without the overhead and expense
of managing capacity or infrastructure.

In addition to this fundamental differentiation, 
Glue’s user interface provides a unique authoring

experience that accommodates user 
different preferences and skillsets.

Business users can get started quickly 
by building visual ETL jobs, while more

technical data engineers can create 
advanced jobs using custom code.
Let’s take a look.
We’ll begin in AWS Glue,

where we can move and transform 
data by authoring or editing an ETL job.

We can create a new job by selecting one of the 
starting points, or we can edit an existing job.
We’ll look at an existing visual job first.

This job joins two data sources together and 
writes the output to an Amazon S3 bucket.
We can click on any node to learn more about it.

We can view or modify its 
properties in the panel on the right,

and preview the data or output 
schema in the lower panel.
We can easily add nodes.

On the Transforms tab, we can choose 
how we want to transform our data.

On the Data tab, we can browse 
the available data sources.

With the visual editor, we can define 
data integration jobs to meet our business
needs without needing to write any code.

If we want to work with the underlying 
code, we can view and edit the job’s script.

Let’s copy the script that was generated
for the data node so we can use it later.

Next, we’ll set up a Jupyter notebook, 
which is an interactive job authoring

environment that allows engineers to test 
and debug code quickly using sample data.
Here is our AWS Glue Studio notebook.

We can modify these parameters 
based on our expected workload,

and then run the cell to 
initialize the interactive session.
The notebook has been initialized.
We can add a section by clicking the plus icon.

Let’s paste in the data 
script code we copied earlier.

To run the code, we can press Shift + Enter 
on Windows, or Command + Enter on Mac.
The blue bar tells us the code ran without error.

If our edited code includes mistakes, 
the notebook will display an orange
bar so we know to make corrections.

We can add a section to show
 how the data looks at this step.
Let's run the code.
The interactive preview allows us to see

the data state and ensure the data 
formats are correct at this step.
Let’s remove this section.
Now let’s save the notebook to turn it into a job.

Using the tabs in the notebook editor, 
we have the same options for working
with the job as we did in the visual editor.

Next, let’s look at how we can make code 
we’ve developed available to a no-code user.

Let's return to the visual ETL 
job that we reviewed earlier.

We can add a custom data transform that business
 users can access from here and apply to their jobs.

This documentation page includes step-
by-step instructions for setting up a
custom visual transform in AWS Glue.

Once we’ve defined the code and 
uploaded the transform to Amazon S3,

it will be available to users through 
the AWS Glue Studio visual interface.

Let’s select a custom transform that is 
already set up in the visual ETL editor.
The transform has been added to this ETL job.

In this way, data engineers can write 
business-specific ETL logic and share
it in a central way with users of varying skillsets.

You’ve just learned about AWS 
Glue data integration differentiators.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it's your turn to try.
